resources.string: Carbon was inspired by Berkley Earth\'s findings about the relation between air pollution and smoking. The rule is simple : one cigarette per day is roughly equivalent to a PM 2.5 level of 22μg/m³.(1) Then, it calculates the reduction in life span from the study conducted by EPIC (University of Chicago) which states that for every additional 10 μg/m³ of PM 2.5, life span reduces by roughly 1 year.(2)
How does Carbon calculate the amount of years your lifespan has been reduced by?
Why the results for weekly and monthly smoked cigarettes might not be 100% accurate?

The feature of displaying monthly and weekly cigarettes is in beta because we simply multiply the current level of PM 2.5 to account for a week and a month. For the full feature, we are working on gathering data that contains the history of PM 2.5 levels of a location, so we can provide accurate estimations.
Where does the AQI data come from?
Real time air quality data comes from a free API by WAQI team and the EPA in the form of AQI levels which are usually updated every one hour.
